I liked this film less than Modern Times, The Kid, The Gold Rush or City Lights. Why? There are several reasons for it. First of all, to my mind, Chaplin's films about The Tramp are much better being silent than talking. In his previous films Charles demonstrated us how beautifully he managed to show everything without dialoges. These films were much funnier. In The Great Dictator we have some moments of visual humor, but they are more rare and less funny. I really liked about 10 moments, especially the one with pudding, but in other Chaplin's movies I laughed or smiled all throughout the film. So the main disadvantage of this picture is having just a few really funny moments, though film is much longer than other ones about The Tramp. I know what Charles intented to make laugh at, but maybe war isn't the topic he made best films about. Many dialoges are dull or pointless, as well as some scenes in the movie. But others I liked. For instance, the way the barber is represented or his last speech. The speech is really great and is much better than other dialoges in this movie. It's a shame that people still don't understand the things Chaplin said.All in all, this is not the best film about The Tramp, not the best comedy about WW2 (in this respect I like Life is Beautiful and Jojo Rabbit more), and not the best film about war either. But it's definitely not a bad movie. Its humorous jokes, final speech and some other moments still make it a good movie, though not as good as other Chaplin's movies.

reviews.review_title: Brightening The Darkest Moments With a Wink and a Smile
reviews.content: "In this land of the crazy the sane are mad", wrote Edmund Cooper. This 1940 Chaplin classic is as great an example of that phenomenon as you will find. Yes, it is indeed strange that Chaplin's Adenoid Hynkel should pull spaghetti apart in frustration, whilst arguing with his dictatorial rival in the shape of Jack Oakie's Napoloni; but how much stranger, darker and ultimately madder were the hatreds engendered, crimes committed and murders perpetrated during the run up to, and through the course of, WW2? A satire has to contain recognisable human characteristics, instincts and foibles - when this was made it was known how bad Nazism was, but not the extent of the persecution, death camps and ethnic cleansing. A quite extraordinary line in the film about the discovery of a wonder poison gas, acutely and poignantly envisages the ultimate madness, the gas chambers.The delightful scene in which Hynkel plays footie with an inflated globe, bouncing it twice on his buttocks, before finding it burst in his grasp, is a great metaphor for Hitler's megalomania; and the touching Paulette Goddard, who plays Hannah, is both willing to take on the stormtroopers and go out with an amnesia suffering, older Jewish barber, living below her parents rooms - boy, if I could achieve such social success, I'd grab the scissors right now and forget all things good, bad or indifferent beforehand.Chaplin's final soliloquy may be deemed somewhat pretentious, but his condemnation of anti-semitism and call for racial tolerance amongst black and white, all classes, races and creeds, should be pinned to the wall of every UN representative's office, right now. 21st Century audiences can learn as much from this film as 20th Century ones. Hynkel and Napoloni may be buffoons, but this acerbic classic is as potent now as it was then. Buffoonery can sometimes, just sometimes, be evil.

reviews.review_title: My Personal Favourite of Chaplin's Work
reviews.content:
Chaplin is a wizard. In this he furthers his ability of comedy but combines it with drama to make for in my opinion his best movie. Both his writing and his acting in this are superb, culminating in one of the best writen scenes with acting so good it's bound to give you chills. Chaplin plays two characters in the movie, one of which is the dictator. The dictator is clearly satire as the moustache and all of the ludicrous decisions he makes are him pretending to be Hitler. This role holds up to day with the power of hindsight and warning us about those who do not learn from history are condemned to repeat it, but also it would have worked especially well then, in 1940, whilst the Second World War was happening and being propaganda. He also plays a Jewish barber, which ties in with the insanity of the plot, how Chaplin hates his other character and vice versa. The Jewish barber is a clear and obvious juxtaposition to the Great Dictator, the Jewish barber being the best of humanity dancing and singing etc whilst the great dictator is meant to be the worst, causing violence unnecessarily and his drive being his ego and the pressure placed in him.
It preaches a strong moral and it is a movie that is a great watch for today in such a political climate. And it's really funny, chaplin's brand of slapstick will always get a laugh out of me.

An overrated film. The satire works very well, especially since Chaplin has sussed that Hynkel-Hitler was the empty puppet of his impulses. But Chaplin can't resist inserting slapstick and farce, which interferes with the developing terror. The Brown Shirts may have been buffoons, but their buffoonery killed people. Chaplin shies away from following the logic of his plot to its dark conclusion. The final scene, obviously meant to be a stirring call to arms against tyranny, turns the plot into sentimental farce. Satire is allied to tragedy, and doesn't need a happy ending to make its point. But perhaps the American audiences of 1940 preferred to laugh at slapdash tyrant instead of considering the moral imperative laid on them by recognising evil.I watched this movie because of its reputation. It's become a curio, important for its historical significance. It did help mobilise American opinion against Hitler. But it's also an example of the muddled mess that Chaplin was capable of producing when not restrained by a strong director. A mixture of inspired satire, slapstick, and comedy, but that's all, a mixture. The movie doesn't have the structure that I expected. It's a series of set pieces loosely strung on an underdeveloped plot line. Too often, I got the impression that Chaplin was showing off, or relying on his audience recognising a shtick he'd used many, many times before.Worth watching if you're a Chaplin fan, or if you want to understand how old movies coudl affect public opinion.

Charlie Chaplin's The Great Dictator was published in 1940. It's Chaplin's first sound film. Chaplin plays two roles in the movie. It was banned in some countries for many years especially in dictatorships.Adenoid Hynkel (Chaplin) is the dictator of Tomainia. He is a fascist who hates democracy and Jews. Hynkel would like to invade Osterlich. Ministers Garbitsch and Herring are his loyal helpers. At the same time a Jewish barber (Chaplin) return from hospital after 20 years where he was from the end of World War I, because he lost his memory. He doensn't know anything about Hynkel or his regime. The barber meets again his old friends who tell him about the current state of Tomainia. Commander Schultz who has decided to defy Hynkel meets the barber who has rescued the commander during World War I. Later Schultz and the barber try to save Osterlich when the barber pretends to be Hynkel. Hannah (Paulette Goddard) is the barber's neighbour and the object of his love.It's very strange to watch Chaplin movie which is a sound movie. The movie is still very good. Chaplin had many great silent movies. I like them little more. The Great Dictator is a great parody and drama in the same package. Scenes which contains music and little talk are definitely the best. Main characters are memorable and some side characters are very funny. The movie could have been little shorter. Occasional overacting isn't credible. Chaplin's slapstick comedy is very funny as always. The script is full of political satire like a country called Bacteria or a dictator called Benzino Napaloni. The last scene is really emotional and impressive. The Great Dictator is Chaplin's personal appeal against dictators. 9/10.

reviews.review_title: This one lived up to expectations.
reviews.content: I can recall my brother (3 years older) talking about seeing this one back in 1957 or so, and I saw a few print references over the years, but in that pre-VCR-DVD-Downlaod age the only way you caught a classic movie was on the tube (3 networks plus independent stations depending on where you lived) so I didn't see this one until I was in college in the 1970s, but it lived up to expectations. Chaplin's first talking film and he does a fine job, much of the dialogue is clever and memorable, my favorite line being from the scene where Hynkel is being briefed by Garbitsch, the latter refers to the problems of an austerity regime gearing up for war, in his Henry Daniell voice he mentions "Complaints about the quality of the sawdust in the artificial bread." The casting is inspired, Henry Daniell as "Garbitsch", Billy Gilbert as "Herring" and Jack Oakie as "Napoloni"-he really did look like Mussolini and has a lot of his mannerisms down pat. I read that much of Chaplin's best dialogue were the speeches he gave in mock-German, they are effective, I speak enough German to know that is what "Der Fooey" sounded like, and the scene where Hynkel says "mussten skrimpen und saven und tighten den belten" and Herring jumps up and says "Hail Hynkel, Ich will been den firsten", the timing is superb and is worth waiting for.

If Mr. Charlie Chaplin, greatest figure in movie history, abandoned silent films with "The Great Dictator", not to worry: we will stop talking for him. His fantastic portrayal and satiric costume of Nazi Germany has made me (and others I hope) speechless with such genius for art and lirism. A gift for all mankind and a manifesto against hatred, "The Great Dictator" is one of the great movies of all time. Along with most of Chaplin's.
The parody about nazism is not great as the final monologue about Freedom and society that I 'd like to listen every day in my life

reviews.review_title: Contains one of the funniest movie sequences I have ever seen.
reviews.content: The beginning 5 or 10 minutes of this movie contain some of the funniest scenes I can ever remember seeing in any film (except from Chaplin's silent short feature, "Pay Day") - I laughed out loud and so hard, I cried, I thought it was so funny. The remainder of the movie is, of course, typically clever, the humor more low key and very Chaplin-ish. When I first saw it (which is fairly recently), I was quite surprised that it was his first "talkie" - naturally being used to his silent films, I was quite pleasantly surprised by his pleasing voice and that he didn't move to sound earlier. Charlie Chaplin will always remain my favorite performer/artist/director/comic - The Little Tramp.

reviews.review_title: Don't fight for slavery! Fight for liberty!
reviews.content: Charles Chaplin is an acclaimed silent film actor, but you would not be able to tell that from this film. There is plenty of speaking to go around, and it is done quite well for a man who mostly resided in silent films. From an entertainment aspect, the film is sometimes boring, but it is very funny. I did find myself chuckling quite often at what was going on, but overall the entertainment side was lacking. But these 7 stars come from everything else this film brings. At the time, the US had not yet entered WWII. However, 1940 is when Hitler was gaining traction, and his ideas and beliefs spreading throughout the world. This film is a direct parody of everything him and his regime stood for, and that is a BOLD move. Such blatantly obvious criticism of a political party and regime nowadays would seem almost inconceivable. But Chaplin did it. The speech that the Jewish Barber delivers at the end is perfect. I don't mean like, "yea it's perfectly place". I mean that every single word in that speech is perfect. The speech itself is quite pertinent in today's society as well - I'm writing this on November 17, 2020 - and stood the test of time for 80 years. A beautiful criticism of hatred and a wonderful plea for love and peace.

I couldn't believe it. Chaplin made the movie in 1940. I hardly ever watch old movies, because, no matter how great they are, it just doesn't fit my current expectations. But, Great Dictator is an exception. I borrowed the two DVD's (one DVD had extra commentaries and color footage behind the scenes taken by Sydney Chaplin, Charley's brother). The movie was well ahead of its time in terms of humour and sophistication. Chaplin in later years said that if he knew the extent of Nazi's atrocities, he would not have made the movie. What a loss it would have been. The interesting thing was that, it was reported Hitler himself saw the movie, though it was banned in Germany at that time. One of the survivors of his inner circles said that Hitler would have definitely laughed hard if he indeed had seen it. What a pity, that he learned nothing from Chaplin's closing minutes in the movie!!!The way Chaplin portrayed the two characters (the Hynckler, or Hitler and the jew barber) was astonishing. While they were two different characters on the set, they were the same actor (Chaplin) and somehow they both related to Hitler. Hitler himself suspected he may have had Jewish blood (one of his close advisors later told him, after extensive research, that there was a 50-50 chance he might be one quarter Jewish), my gut feeling was that he was probably more Jewish that he thought or his advisors told him he was, just because he never liked to listen to what he didn't like to hear!! Then the barber's service in the firs world war (Hitler fought in WWI), and how Germany lost that war while he was hospitalized. And at the end, Chaplin presents a scenario in which the barber, as the new Reich, is leading the country away from death and destruction to peace. I think Chaplin had a feeling that Hitler probably had this other side within him that, if nurtured, would have taken him and the world to a different direction. It was not to be. There was also the opposite forces within Hitler (my personal opinion is that the source of this force was his ultra EGO which the DEVIL itself) that fought with the forces of peace and love. He chose the other way, and became nothing at the end. The movie, in my opinion, also portrays this fact very neatly, as the real Reich sitting in Jail, with his globe balloon burst. Chaplin not only portrayed the past and present in his movie, he some how foresaw the future. It is a great movie.

Funny yet important and 75 years on is still highly topical. This film should be used in schools to educate new generations about the values that a modern and free society protects. Through this parody, a great deal is taught about what not to tolerate as a society, whereby we can discover what values we should strive uphold. Highly inspiring and thought provoking this film will be watched for hundreds of years to come and beyond.The time the film was released also reveals further meaning. It shines an honest light on the Nazi (double cross) atrocities and mocks then in comedic fashion, while tastefully poking fun at the sometimes thuggish foot soldiers, all in good humour and yet wraps it all up in a spiritual message of unity in the closing speech. The whole show is done in such a way as to raise moral of the allies and was not only educational, enlightening and hilarious, but also served to remind everyone what we all really want is peace.10 out of 10 stars.

Possibly one of the most brilliant movies of all time. It shows the work of a comic genius (Charlie Chaplin) as well as an incredibly political insight. This film was panned and saw Chaplin labeled communist. Then after the start of WW2 Chaplin became a genius once again, overnight. Its message, although nearly 60 years old, still rings true in its plea for the end to war. The best political satire ever to be aimed at Hitler. 10/10!!!

Okay, it's too long and it's too satisfied with itself. Still, "The Great Dictator" is a fascinating movie. Chaplin does a terrific job satirizing Hitler and trying to portray the oppression of the Jews in Nazi Germany (this was before the concentration camps were common knowledge). Not a Chaplin masterpiece, but still worth seeing.

The ending speech reminded me of 'Mein Führer - Die wirklich wahrste Wahrheit über Adolf Hitler'. BTW, I watched it when I was 12 approximately, and the ending of Ulrich Mühe being shot was truly stirring for a teenager after a whole movie time foreshadowing without omen.Ulrich Mühe was remarkable in 'Das Leben der Anderen' and I saw this film when I was after 20. Nevertheless I did not know that he was the actor I had seen in teenage time.Back to 'The Great Dictator', disgorging coins and putting them into the pocket was a nice detail for the hero. Analogously, woman at the gala dinner taking some cakes and a loaf of bread was thought-provoking too.Charles Chaplin was a prodigy to write and direct. His subtle countenance and delicious double duty as Hynkel - dictator of Tomania, and as the Jewish barber were amazing. His pilot part was funny. Plus, some special effects shots were stunning even now.But what was really diverting was that I first became aware of this movie when I was reading my history textbook in junior high school but I saw this film by myself until now.

This ingenious and innovate comedy packs many priceless moments and great sense of pace , though overlong . Chaplin's satire with several classic scenes , he has dual role as a Jewish barber and dictator Hynkel , an offensive portrayal of Hitler . Then the barber is mistaken for the Hitlerian tyrant and there happens bemusing events . Funny and extraordinary acting all around , as the stunning co-stars Jack Oakie as Napolini (Mussolini-alike) , Henry Daniel as Gasbstich (Himmler-alike) and Billy Gilbert as Herring (Goering) . Chaplin's first spoken film is brilliantly photographed by Karl Struss . This splendid film contains numerous amusing scenes , the funniest are the followings : 1) The one when during the WWI the barber-soldier along with a co-pilot are flying in a turned plane without to be aware 2) When Dictator Adenoid Hynkel tells overacting speeches , including a twisted microphone 3) Hynkel playing with an enormous world balloon 4) The Jew-barber shaving a man while fitting to Hungarian Dance : number 5 by Brahms 5) when Hynkel and Napolini each try to keep his body higher than other in a barber's chair , among them .Production on the movie started in 1937 and shot in 539 days when not nearly as many people believed Nazism was a menace , as was the case when it was released in 1940 ; however , this film was ultimately upstaged as the first anti-Nazi film satire . Hitler banned movie exhibition to the Germans due to its satire of him , and put him in his death list after his proposed conquest of America . The movie is co-starred by Paulette Goddard , third of his four wives , they were married in 1936 , although no announcement of the marriage was made later, one time finished The Great Dictator . The picture was released in 1940 , when Chaplin had survived a moral scandal by a paternity suit but a brush with the House of Un-American Activities was the signal for the USA to refuse him re-entry from Britain and he fled to Switzerland . This movie was Charles Chaplin's biggest-ever box-office hit , grossing about $5 million at the time.

Along with The Gold Rush, Modern Times and City Lights(my personal favourite) this is one of my favourites from Charlie Chaplin. The Great Dictator is just a wonderful satire on the Anti-Semitic Nazi regime- Hitler mayn't have got the joke in this comedy, but I think he got the point.
